intro: Neomazaea pungens, commonly known as the pungent mistletoe, is a hemiparasitic plant belonging to the Loranthaceae family. It primarily grows on the branches of various host trees, such as oaks and elms, in temperate regions. The plant lacks chlorophyll and relies on its host for water and nutrients, while also deriving some photosynthetic ability from its own leaves. Its small, white or pale green berries are an important food source for birds and other wildlife. Neomazaea pungens plays a role in ecosystem dynamics by influencing host tree growth and providing ecological benefits through seed dispersal.
